awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Research: Characterizing Engineering Student Mental Wellness and Its Role in Predicting Engineering Attrition
awd_abstract_narration:
Both the need for increasing retention rates among engineers, and the correlation between mental wellness and general student success are well documented. However, there has been no comprehensive study exploring the relationships between mental wellness and engineering student success or retention. This studyss contribution is significant because analyzing how mental wellness issues affect students? persistence in engineering and cataloguing a list of mental wellness resources offered by engineering departments allows programs to identify and support at-risk students, increasing their ability to successfully retain and graduate a diverse class of engineers. The outcomes of this project are: 1) characterizations of mental wellness of various engineering student populations, including how prevalence of conditions changes throughout the program and any inequities across demographic groups; 2) characterizations of the relationships between Outcome 1 and intention to persist in engineering; 3) characterization of students? awareness of mental wellness resources available to them; 4) a list of needs or gaps in mental wellness resources for engineering students; 5) a model of engineering student success and retention that accounts for mental wellness, and 6) stakeholder-specific materials and trainings.
 
The goal of this project is to study how student mental wellness factors into persistence for engineering students from all backgrounds. The specific research aims are: 1) to characterize the mental wellness of engineering students and its relationship to persistence, and 2) to characterize institutional practices and services related to mental wellness. The first aim is being accomplished through a mixed-methods, longitudinal study consisting of surveys and interviews with engineering students at both large research-oriented and smaller teaching-oriented engineering schools, and Minority Serving Institutions around the country. The survey is a compilation of validated instruments, and qualitative interviews will be used to explore in-depth themes that emerge from the survey. The second research aim is being accomplished through a survey with participating institutions to collect information on how and to what extent mental wellness resources and materials are incorporated into the engineering program. The education aim is to develop research-based, actionable resources for administrators, counselors, faculty, advisors, and students. This is being accomplished through the development of materials and interactive trainings disseminated to different groups of stakeholders. Each set of materials or trainings targets a specific group of stakeholders and is designed with guidance from mental health professionals. This study is significant because it is the first in-depth study of the relationship between mental wellness and retention specifically for engineering students. Educational materials created enhance intellectual infrastructure locally and nationally by providing the first research-based interventions of this kind.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
This project met its Intellectual Merit goals by producing the first comprehensive and longitudinal nationwide data on engineering students’ mental health overall, and by examining where differences exist between demographic groups. Through annual surveys and interviews with engineering students, the project identified rates of diagnosable mental health conditions among various groups of engineering students, how those rates changed over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic, what aspects of engineering education undermine students’ mental health, and what aspects of college counseling and disability services can be improved to better support engineering students. The project produced numerous conference papers, journal articles, and professional development workshops for engineering faculty members around the country. The conference papers were presented at the 2020 and 2022 Frontiers in Education annual conferences, the 2021–2023 American Society for Engineering Education annual conferences, the 2020 Professional and Organizational Development (POD) Network Annual Conference, the 2020 Australasian Association of Engineering Education conference, and the 2021 European Society of Engineering Education conference. The 2022 ASEE paper won an award for Most Transformative Paper from the LEES Division. The 2020 Frontiers in Education paper was selected as one of the best papers of the conference and invited to be expanded and included in the special 50th anniversary issue of IEEE Transactions on Education (published 2022). Findings were also shared via contributions to an open access report on the impact of COVID-19 on engineering education by Ruth Graham Consultancy. The project’s dissemination efforts contributed to the fields of engineering education, college counseling, and higher education, thus demonstrating the interdisciplinary reach of the project’s findings. 


Broader impacts from this project reached engineering undergraduate students, graduate students, and faculty members, college counseling and disability service centers, and engineering student advisors. Based on findings from the surveys and interviews, stakeholder-specific research briefs were created and shared with key groups of stakeholders, including faculty and advisors, deans, student service providers, and several different groups of students. The briefs contained a summary of the key findings, actionable recommendations, and resources most salient for each group of stakeholders. Individualized institution-specific research briefs were also created for each college of engineering with which we partnered for data collection purposes. Research briefs can inform policy change with recommendations for policies that will better support students’ mental health. Additionally, this project contributes to broadening participation in engineering by identifying ways in which engineering education systems and student services can better support neurodiverse engineering students, as well as by providing a comprehensive understanding of how different demographic groups of engineering students nationwide are experiencing mental health challenges, including intersectional patterns.


Last Modified: 11/28/2023
Modified by: Andrew Danowitz
